question.name: The three largest earthquakes occurred in: San Francisco, Tokyo, and Lima.
question.questiontext: The three largest earthquakes occurred in: San Francisco, Tokyo, and Lima.
question.generalfeedback: The three largest earthquakes occurred in San Francisco, Tokyo, and Lima.

question.name: According to Dr. D. Simpson [1986], a biologist at the Harvard Medical School...
question.questiontext: According to Dr. D. Simpson [1986], a biologist at the Harvard Medical School, "Only 30,000 rads are needed for interphase death to occur in yeast cells".
question.generalfeedback: According to Dr. D. Simpson [1986], a biologist at the Harvard Medical School, "Only 30,000 rads are needed for interphase death to occur in yeast cells."

question.name: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the ...
question.questiontext: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone; see Appendix A.
question.generalfeedback: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone, as discussed in Appendix A.

question.name: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the ...
question.questiontext: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone - see Appendix A.
question.generalfeedback: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone -- see Appendix A. The em-dash can be represented by two hyphens, but not one as in the original sentence.

question.name: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the ...
question.questiontext: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone (See Appendix A.)
question.generalfeedback: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone (see Appendix A).

question.name: The absorption A is calculated by:A = 1 - kR, where k is the correction facto...
question.questiontext:
The absorption A is calculated by:
A = 1 - kR,
where k is the correction factor and R is the measured reflectance.
question.generalfeedback:
The absorption A is calculated by
A = 1 - kR,
where k is the correction factor and R is the measured reflectance.

question.name: Which of the following appear in italics?
question.questiontext: Which of the following appear in italics?
question.generalfeedback: Use italics for large documents: titles of books; titles of journals, periodicals, and newspapers; titles of reports longer than 75 pages; titles of full-length films; titles of record albums; and titles of large web sites.

answer.answertext: book title and title of journal article
book title and title of periodical
chapter title and title of periodical
chapter title and title of journal article

question.name: Which of the following appear in quotation marks (“”)?
question.questiontext: Which of the following appear in quotation marks (“”)?
question.generalfeedback: Use quotation marks for short documents: chapter titles of books; article titles from journals, periodicals, and newspapers; titles of reports shorter than 75 pages; titles of short films; titles of songs; and titles of individual web pages.

answer.answertext: book title and title of journal article
book title and title of periodical
chapter title and title of periodical
chapter title and title of journal article

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 4 - Advanced Exercises on Grammar, Punctuation, and Usage
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 4 - Advanced Exercises on Grammar, Punctuation, and Usage'.

question.name: Paragraph 1
question.questiontext:
A greenhouse is a glass building used to grow plants.

{#1}

A greenhouse has transparent glass that allows the sunlight

{#2}

to pass through, but does not allow the heat inside

{#3}

to escape. The same affect occurs on the earth.

{#4}

The suns radiation passes through the atmosphere to heat

{#5}

the earth's surface. When heated, the earth's surface

{#6}

produces infrared radiation, which has a longer

{#7}

wavelength than that of sunlight. This infrared radiation

 

rises into the atmosphere where gases, such as

{#8}

carbon dioxide, prevents the infrared radiation from

{#9}

escaping into space. The concentrations of these

 

gases which are called greenhouse gases, control how much

{#10}

infrared radiation escapes. The retained radiation heats

 

the earth's atmosphere, thus keeping the planet warm.

{#11}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#sun’s}

question.name: Paragraph 1
question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.name: Paragraph 1

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#prevent}

question.name: Paragraph 2
question.questiontext:
During the last century, the concentrations of greenhouse

 

gases have increased substantially [Holman, 1985].

{#1}

Scientists believe that further increases could cause excess

{#2}

warming of the earth's climate. Moreover, many scientists

{#3}

believe this warming could produce side effects.

{#4}

For example, the changing of the earth's wind patterns.

{#5}

These wind patterns control the amount of rain received in a

 

particular area. If the greenhouse gases warm the earth's climate

{#6}

too much, areas that now receive plenty of rainfall could

 

become deserts, moreover, some scientists speculate that

{#7}

additional increases in warming could cause another

 

effect, a rise in the ocean levels ["Greenhouse," 1990]. How would

{#8}

this rise occur? An increase in global temperature would melt the

 

polar ice caps, thus emptying more water into the oceans.

{#9}

They also predict that this ocean

{#10}

rise, which may well

{#11}

be as high as 1

{#12}

meter could flood port cities and coastal lands.

{#13}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#This is not a sentence.}

answer.feedback: This is not a sentence.

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#deserts; moreover, …}

question.name: Paragraph 2
question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.name: Paragraph 2
question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#one}

answer.feedback: one

question.name: Paragraph 2

question.name: Paragraph 3
question.questiontext:
The gas that contributes most to the greenhouse

{#1}

effect, is carbon dioxide [Houghton, 1990]. Carbon

{#2}

dioxide cannot be seen, smelled, or tasted.

{#3}

In fact, its not even considered a pollutant.

{#4}

Plants use carbon dioxide in combination with

 

chlorophyll, water, and sunshine for photosynthesis, which is

{#5}

a process essential to life. Besides aiding in photosynthesis, it

{#6}

will also absorb the earth's radiation. This gas occurs naturally in the

 

atmosphere, however, man has dramatically increased

{#7}

the concentration of carbon dioxide over the last twenty years.

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.name: Paragraph 3
question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#effect is}

answer.feedback: effect is

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:=Okay~Wrong}

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#it is}

answer.feedback: it is

question.questiontext: {1:MCH:Okay~=Wrong#they}

answer.feedback: they

answer.feedback: atmosphere; however,

question_category.name: Default for Article 1: Exercise
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Article 1: Exercise'.

question.name: Question 1
question.questiontext:
Page 57, Column 2, Line 5

However, this approach allows only one-hop clusters to be formed and the hot spot problem does not be considered.

  • The correct structure should be: ... the hot spot problem {#1} considered.

question.name: Question 1
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=is not#Form a proper passive structure}

answer.feedback: Form a proper passive structure

question.name: Question 2
question.questiontext:
Page 57, Column 2, Line 15

Olariu and Stojmenovic (2006) presented the first theoretical work to analyze avoidance of the energy hole problem and it has been proven that the unbalanced energy depletion is intrinsic and no routing strategy can avoid under some specific conditions in this study.

  • The correct structure should be: ... no routing strategy {#1} under some specific conditions in this study.

question.name: Question 2
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=can be avoided#"can avoid WHAT"; which structure do we use when the object is not present?}

answer.feedback: "can avoid WHAT"; which structure do we use when the object is not present?

question.name: Question 3
question.questiontext:
Page 58, Column 1, Line 3

However, it shows somewhat an unrealistic architecture since they assume that CHs with super power are deployed or move to the best position where minimizes energy consumption.

  • The correct structure should be: ... the best position {#1} minimizes energy consumption.

question.name: Question 3
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=which~=that#"where" is always followed by S+V}

answer.feedback: "where" is always followed by S+V

question.name: Question 4
question.questiontext:
Page 58, Column 1, Line 27

Theoretical analysis and simulation studies show that EB-UCP outperforms in terms of balancing energy dissipation among sensor nodes and enlarging the lifetime of networks than EEUC and LEACH.

  • In this sentence, the problem word is {#1}.

question.name: Question 4
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=than#Can you see a comparison structure in this sentence?}

answer.feedback: Can you see a comparison structure in this sentence?

question.name: Question 5
question.questiontext:
Page 59, Column 1, Paragraph 3, Sentence 1

Each node in every layer become a tentative CH with the same probability pt which is defined by Eq. 3.

  • The correct structure should be: Each node in every layer {#1} a tentative CH ...

question.name: Question 5
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=becomes#There is no subject-verb agreement!}

answer.feedback: There is no subject-verb agreement!

question.name: Question 6
question.questiontext:
Page 59, Column 1, Paragraph 3, Line 9

After the construction of SCH has been finished in lines 7-8, each tentative CH checks its SCH and makes a decision whether it can become a CH in lines 9-19.

  • Instead of finished, the correct synonym would be {#1}.

question.name: Question 6
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=completed~=finalized~=finalised#"= bring to a conclusion"}

answer.feedback: "= bring to a conclusion"

question.name: Question 7
question.questiontext:
Page 61, Column 1, SIMULATION RESULTS, Line 9

The experiments described in this part have been conducted with the aid of a well known simulation tool, Ns2.

  • Although this use is acceptable, a better way of introducing Ns2 would be {#1}

question.name: Question 7
question.questiontext: {1:MCV:~a well-known simulation tool, Ns2~=Ns2, a well known simulation tool#First the item, after that its description!}

answer.answertext: Ns2, a well known simulation tool
answer.feedback: First the item, after that its description!

question.name: Question 8
question.questiontext:
Page 61, Column 2, Energy Efficiency, Sentence 1

In this subsection, the performance of EB-UCP, EEUC and LEACH in terms of network lifetime are compared.

  • The correct structure should be: In this subsection, {#1} of ...

question.name: Question 8
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=the performances~=performances#There is on subject-verb agreement!}

answer.feedback: There is on subject-verb agreement!

question.name: Question 9
question.questiontext:
Page 61, Column 2, Energy Efficiency, Line 6

Compared with the EB-UCP and EEUC, CHs in LEACH sends their packets to the sink node via single hop and the energy consumption is much higher.

  • The correct structure should be: Compared with the EB-UCP andEEUC, CHs in LEACH {#1} their packets ...

question.name: Question 9
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=send#There is no subject-verb agreement!}

answer.feedback: There is no subject-verb agreement!

question.name: Question 10
question.questiontext:
Page 62, CONCLUSION, Sentence 1

The hot spot problem appears when employing the multihop routing in a clustering approach.

  • The correct structure should be: ... when {#1}

question.name: Question 10
question.questiontext: {1:SA:=the multihop routing is employed#Who is employing what?}

answer.feedback: Who is employing what?

question_category.name: Default for Article 2: Exercise
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Article 2: Exercise'.

question.name: Page 1, ABSTRACT The integration of decision science into design techniques ...
question.questiontext:
Page 1, ABSTRACT
The integration of decision science into design techniques in Engineering and Engineering Technology programs is necessary to provide graduating engineers the necessary skills to become more immediate contributors to the goals and profits of their chosen companies.
question.generalfeedback: to provide SOMEONE with SOMETHING

answer.answertext: I think one preposition is missing.
This is too long for an "abstract".

question.name: Page 1, I. INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND How do you get the most rigidity for ...
question.questiontext:
Page 1, I. INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND
How do you get the most rigidity for the least cost and, in many cases, at the lowest weight? That is to say, “the most bang for your buck.”
question.generalfeedback: Do not ask direct questions in academic writing! Another question appears on page 5 (highlighted). By the way, “the most bang for your buck” is colloquial but there is no problem with it because it is given between quotation marks.

answer.answertext: This is not suitable for an academic paper.
The second "sentence" is not a sentence at all.
I love this man's style. I can't see what is wrong with it!

question.name: Page 1, II. PROBLEM STATEMENT A. Definitions and Scope
question.questiontext:
Page 1, II. PROBLEM STATEMENT
A. Definitions and Scope
question.generalfeedback: That is right! And this is not the only place where this mistake occurs. See "A. Decision Matrix" on page 6.

answer.answertext: Let me guess .... there is no "B"?
Can it be that the title does not reflect the content?
I still insist that this man's style is wonderful!

question.name: Page 3, A. Integration of Shape Effect Thus, both steel and aluminum are very...
question.questiontext:
Page 3, A. Integration of Shape Effect
Thus, both steel and aluminum are very similar if looking only at the amount of stiffness per pound of weight, not considering the shape of the cross section.
question.generalfeedback: When we use a gerund structure after “if”, “when”, “while”, etc., there CAN be only one subject in the sentence.

answer.answertext: "Pound" should be "kilo"? But he is American!
We need a "not only ... but also" structure.
Both steel and aluminium are looking at something.

question.name: Page 4 Bar A is significantly more rigid (16 times!) than bar B.
question.questiontext:
Page 4
Bar A is significantly more rigid (16 times!) than bar B.
question.generalfeedback: The finding can be surprising or even appalling; yet, we cannot use exclamation marks in academic writing to indicate this. The same use appears on top of page 5 (highlighted).

answer.answertext: The phrase in brackets has no place here.
If I were the author, I would use something like this: (16 times!!!)

question.name: Page 4 Intuitively, envision a 50.8 mm x 203.2 mm (2" x 8") piece of ...
question.questiontext:
Page 4
Intuitively, envision a 50.8 mm x 203.2 mm (2" x 8") piece of dimension lumber.
question.generalfeedback: That is right; “envision …” is a direct request/command. Similarly, there are two more sentences like this one (highlighted) on the same page, and on page 5 (highlighted).

answer.answertext: This one is easy! No "order" or "request" in a scientific paper!
Why are you always trying to find mistakes in his paper? He is a good man!

question.name: Page 5, (3) Rearrangement of (2) Thus, an aluminum I-beam has greater ...
question.questiontext:
Page 5, (3) Rearrangement of (2)
Thus, an aluminum I-beam has greater rigidity than the steel bar and weighs 12.81 kg (28.23 lbs) less!

answer.answertext: Once again, the exclamation mark is unnecessary.
The comparison is not clear at all.

question.name: Page 5, C. Integration of Cost Factor Cost will be the next consideration. ...
question.questiontext:
Page 5, C. Integration of Cost Factor
Cost will be the next consideration. This must be introduced in almost all comparative design processes. This is the part missed in many typical courses.
question.generalfeedback: Do not use terms that will lead to ambiguity. Example? A British parliament said, during a parliament session, “Half of this parliament is stupid!” When he was asked to correct his statement, he said, “I apologize. Half of this parliament is not stupid.”

question.name: Page 5, C. Integration of Cost Factor So on an actual cost basis, the ...
question.questiontext:
Page 5, C. Integration of Cost Factor
So on an actual cost basis, the aluminum I-beam is less expensive, significantly lighter weight, and more rigid.
question.generalfeedback: That is right.

answer.answertext: It is not a good idea to start a sentence with "so".

question.name: Page 6 • Use the above five Rating Factors to rate each Design Criteria for ...
question.questiontext:
Page 6

  • Use the above five Rating Factors to rate each Design Criteria for each of the Design Alternatives.
  • Multiply each Rating Factor by each of the weighting factors and obtain a value for each Design Alternative.
  • Finally, the best design alternative is determined by summing the respective Value
  • Columns within the decision matrix. The column with the highest sum is the best choice.
question.generalfeedback: When you make a list like this, make sure that there is uniformity. For example: 1. Phrase 2. Phrase 3. Phrase. Also, most probably, the author added a line break after “Value” by mistake and divided a long sentence.

answer.answertext: This one is obvious. The listing is totally wrong.
The "full stop" is missing at the end of the sentence.

question.name: Page 7, V. CONCLUSIONS In most cases, companies are looking for an sufficient...
question.questiontext:
Page 7, V. CONCLUSIONS
In most cases, companies are looking for an sufficient design that is the lowest cost or the lightest weight.
question.generalfeedback: a sufficient design

answer.answertext: The choice of tense is wrong.

question.name: Page 7, V. CONCLUSIONS In many situations, it is possible [to satisfy both ...
question.questiontext:
Page 7, V. CONCLUSIONS
In many situations, it is possible [to satisfy both conditions (the low cost and lightest weight)] as shown in the example above.
question.generalfeedback: Actually, the square brackets should be deleted. Also, the correct use is: ( … […] …).

answer.answertext: The meaning is hard to grasp due to the brackets.
We use "the above example", not "the example above".
The author does not explain "which" situations.

question.name: Page 7Gary is a Registered Professional Engineer in the State of Ohio.
question.questiontext:
Page 7
Gary is a Registered Professional Engineer in the State of Ohio.

answer.feedback: That is right.

answer.answertext: This piece of information is not necessary here.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 1 - Recognizing Run-Ons and Fragments (Basic)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 1 - Recognizing Run-Ons and Fragments (Basic)'.

question.questiontext: Although the shock sphere is still strong at the end of the fireball's life, the sphere is no longer strong enough to heat the air to incandescence.
question.generalfeedback: No grammatical mistake exists.

question.questiontext: At that point the shock sphere is no longer strong enough to heat the air to incandescence, however, the sphere is still very strong.
question.generalfeedback: At that point, the shock sphere is no longer strong enough to heat the air to incandescence. However, the sphere is very strong. / … incandescence; however, …

question.questiontext: At the end of the fireball's life, the shock sphere no longer being strong enough to heat the air to incandescence.
question.generalfeedback: At the end of the fireball's life, the shock sphere is no longer strong enough to heat the air to incandescence.

question.questiontext: Both sites produce the same three sources of energy: coal, oil, and natural gas. Both sites, however, do not produce these sources in the same proportions.
question.generalfeedback: No grammatical mistake exists.

question.questiontext: The plant shutdown was more than just another company having to close its doors, Bolens was a way of life for hundreds of families in the small town where the company was located.
question.generalfeedback: The plant shutdown was more than just another company having to close its doors – Bolens was a way of life for hundreds of families in the small town where the company was located.

question.questiontext: Both designs produce the same three pollutants (nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxides, and hydrocarbons) in roughly the same proportions, therefore, both designs have similar effects on the environment.
question.generalfeedback: Both designs produce the same three pollutants (nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxides, and hydrocarbons) in roughly the same proportions. Therefore, both designs have similar effects on the environment. / … proportions; therefore, both …

question.questiontext: Because both designs produce the same three pollutants (nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxides, and hydrocarbons) in roughly the same proportions, both designs have similar effects on the environment.
question.generalfeedback: No grammatical mistake exists.

question.questiontext: An oval shape is necessary in the die cavity, otherwise, the flow of metal from the hammering would be restricted.
question.generalfeedback: An oval shape is necessary in the die cavity; otherwise, the flow of metal from the hammering would be restricted.

question.questiontext: Not only does fresh ventilation reduce moisture levels in animal pens, but it also improves the health and longevity of livestock.
question.generalfeedback: No grammatical mistake exists.

question.questiontext: Primary bodies are those that are outside the zone of protection, thus, they are susceptible to the effects of a direct lightning stroke.
question.generalfeedback: Primary bodies are those that are outside the zone of protection. Thus, they are susceptible to the effects of a direct lightning stroke. / … protection; thus, they are …

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 2 - Parallelism, Pronoun References, and Modifier Placement
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 2 - Parallelism, Pronoun References, and Modifier Placement'.

question.questiontext: (A) Although design flaws in the Titanic were realized soon after its sinking in 1912, the reasons for the severe damage inflicted by the iceberg remained a mystery until (B) its (C) discovery in 1985.
question.generalfeedback: Incorrect pronoun reference. Although the writer intended the second "its" to refer to the Titanic, someone could misread the reference to be the iceberg. To correct, change the second "its" to "Titanic's."

question.questiontext: (A) Once the earthquake has subsided, you are not yet out of danger. Often the electricity has gone out and it is dark. However, (B) striking a match (C) or any open flame may cause a gas explosion.
question.generalfeedback: Faulty parallelism. The gerundial phrase "striking a match" is not parallel with the noun phrase "any open flame." Moreover, the position of "striking" causes an ambiguity: Are open flames to be struck? To correct, replace the words "striking a match" with "a lit match."

question.questiontext: (A) At this time, the Department of Energy is (B) only (C) considering Yucca Mountain as a possible storage site for nuclear waste. (D) For that reason, (E) this report will not consider other sites.
question.generalfeedback: Misplaced modifier. Although the writer intended the word "only" to modify "Yucca Mountain," someone could easily assume that the word modifies "considering." To correct, move "only" such that it precedes "Yucca Mountain."

question.questiontext: (A) Scientists have problems assuring that the viral vectors apply themselves to the correct cells. (B) When implanted, (C) they (D) tend to migrate throughout the body and miss targeted cells more often than not.
question.generalfeedback: Incorrect pronoun reference. To avoid confusion, the word "they" should be "vectors."

question.questiontext: (A) Reductions of up to 80 percent in heat and mass transfer coefficients (B) were measured (C) due to outgassing.
question.generalfeedback: Misplaced modifier. Were the reductions measured because of outgassing, or were the reductions at the level of 80 percent because of outgassing? Because the writer intended the second possibility, the sentence should be rewritten: "Measured were reductions of up to 80 percent in heat and mass transfer coefficients. These large reductions occurred because of outgassing."

question.questiontext: (A) The objectives of the Viking mission were to obtain high-resolution images of the Martian surface, (B) characterize the structure and composition of the atmosphere and surface, (C) and to search for evidence of life.
question.generalfeedback: Faulty parallelism. The list of three verb phrases is not parallel. To correct, insert the word "to" before "characterize."

question.questiontext: (A) Mars and Earth are similar (B) in that (C) both are rapidly rotating planets (D) and both have seasonal climate changes.
question.generalfeedback: Note that “in that” means “because”!

question.questiontext: (A) The decoder was (B) either (C) faster than the worst case specified by the manufacturer, or the HC11 held the data longer than the minimum time specified by Motorola.
question.generalfeedback: Faulty parallelism. With an either/or construction, what appears on the right of the "either" must be parallel with what appears on the right side of the "or." Either the decoder was faster than the worst case specified by the manufacturer, or the HC11 held the data longer than the minimum time specified by Motorola.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 3 - Recognizing Run-Ons and Fragments (Advanced)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 3 - Recognizing Run-Ons and Fragments (Advanced)'.

question.questiontext: Both bombs produce the same three effects: heat, blast, and radiation; however, the bombs do not produce the effects in the same proportions.
question.generalfeedback: No problem.

question.questiontext: Both bombs produce the same three effects: heat, blast, and radiation. The first of which usually causes the most fatalities.
question.generalfeedback: Both bombs produce the same three effects: heat, blast, and radiation. The first of these three usually causes the most fatalities. The original second group of words is a fragment. The word "which" makes that second group of words a dependent clause, which by definition cannot stand alone as a sentence.

question.questiontext: Heat, blast, and radiation are the bomb's three main effects, the first of which usually causes the most fatalities.
question.generalfeedback: No problem.

question.questiontext: Both Mars and Earth are rapidly rotating planets, both have seasonal climate changes, and both have heat exchange of solar radiation between the atmosphere and the surface.
question.generalfeedback: No problem.

question.questiontext: The Great Comet of 1811 not only had a large nucleus (between 30 and 40 kilometers), it also had a large coma, extending a length the diameter of the Sun.
question.generalfeedback: The Great Comet of 1811 not only had a large nucleus (between 30 and 40 kilometers), but it also had a large coma, extending a length the diameter of the Sun. The original group of words is technically a run-on, although it is accepted as a sentence in many informal writing situations. To make it an undisputed sentence, you should add the coordinating conjunction "but."

question.questiontext: The higher the temperature, the lower the pressure.
question.generalfeedback: The higher the temperature is, the lower the pressure is. This group of words is a technically a fragment that almost everyone lets pass as a sentence. Most people would treat this word grouping as having an understood verb in both the dependent clause and the independent clause (much as a command has the understood subject "you"). Should you feel uncomfortable with treating this word grouping as a sentence, simply add the verbs in the dependent and independent clauses.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 7 – Word Choice (Basic)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 7 – Word Choice (Basic)'.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext:
Choose the correct usage in the sentences below.

  1. We produced a small {#1} of automobiles this year – only 530,000.

  2. The serum had serious side {#2}.

  3. Every 250 years, Pluto completes {#3} orbit about the sun.

  4. When a photon in that energy range strikes the atom, the atom {#4} one of its outer electrons.

  5. The talk centered {#5} virtual work.

  6. This report discusses how the eruption {#6} the surrounding terrain.

  7. Last year, Japan {#7} the world in automobile sales.

  8. We then sent the broken part to John Brooks, {#8} the laser group had recommended.

  9. Reduced weight was the {#9} reason for choosing aluminium.

  10. Neither the engineers nor the technicians {#10} hurt in the blaze.

  11. We produced a small number of automobiles this year, even {#11} than last year.

  12. All the bombings involved explosives {#12} contained the chemicals PETN and RDX.

  13. All the bombings involved Semtex {#13} contains the chemicals PETN and RDX.

  14. The talk was mainly on the {#14} of virtual work.

  15. {#15} the antibodies will destroy the cancer cells.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:amount~=number#The word "number" is appropriate because the sentence refers to a quantity that can be counted.}

answer.feedback: The word "number" is appropriate because the sentence refers to a quantity that can be counted.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:affects~=effects}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=its~it's}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:looses~=loses#The verb "lose" means to part with or to miss from one's possession. The word "loose" is generally used as an adjective, meaning not rigidly fastened. When used as a verb, "loose" means to let loose and implies a conscious act, something an electron does not perform.}

answer.feedback: The verb "lose" means to part with or to miss from one's possession. The word "loose" is generally used as an adjective, meaning not rigidly fastened. When used as a verb, "loose" means to let loose and implies a conscious act, something an electron does not perform.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:in~=on}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=affected#affect = have an effect upon; effect = produce, act so as to bring into existence~effected}

answer.feedback: affect = have an effect upon; effect = produce, act so as to bring into existence

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:lead~=led#The word "led" is the past tense of the verb "to lead".}

answer.feedback: The word "led" is the past tense of the verb "to lead".

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:who~=whom#The word "who" is used for the subject of the dependent clause; "whom" is used for the direct object, indirect object, or object of a preposition in the dependent clause.}

answer.feedback: The word "who" is used for the subject of the dependent clause; "whom" is used for the direct object, indirect object, or object of a preposition in the dependent clause.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=principal~principle}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=were~were not}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=fewer#The word "fewer" is appropriate because the sentence refers to a quantity that can be counted.~less}

answer.feedback: The word "fewer" is appropriate because the sentence refers to a quantity that can be counted.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=that~, which}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:that~=, which}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:principal~=principle}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:Hopefully, ~=It is hoped that#The word “hopefully” means in a manner full of hope, not “it is hoped that”. A correct use would be as follows: "We looked hopefully to the courts for a ruling on the contract dispute. In addition, “it is hoped that” is the relevant structure for academic writing.}

answer.feedback: The word “hopefully” means in a manner full of hope, not “it is hoped that”. A correct use would be as follows: "We looked hopefully to the courts for a ruling on the contract dispute. In addition, “it is hoped that” is the relevant structure for academic writing.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 5 – Punctuation: Commas
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 5 – Punctuation: Commas'.

question.name: The new material, which will be available next week is composed of plastic ...
question.questiontext: The new material, which will be available next week is composed of plastic and iodine.
question.generalfeedback: The new material, which will be available next week, is composed of plastic and iodine.

question.name: As World War II escalated the United States became locked into a race with ...
question.questiontext: As World War II escalated the United States became locked into a race with Germany to develop the first atomic bomb.
question.generalfeedback: As World War II escalated, the United States became locked into a race with Germany to develop the first atomic bomb.

question.name: The three largest earthquakes occurred in San Francisco, Tokyo, and Lima.
question.questiontext: The three largest earthquakes occurred in San Francisco, Tokyo, and Lima.
question.generalfeedback: While the comma following "Tokyo" is optional, it is certainly not incorrect.

question.name: On February 5, 1990 Mount St. Helens had another eruption, this one smaller ...
question.questiontext: On February 5, 1990 Mount St. Helens had another eruption, this one smaller than the eruption 10 years before.
question.generalfeedback: On February 5, 1990, Mount St. Helens had another eruption, this one smaller than the eruption 10 years before.

question.name: Every year, an earthquake of magnitude between 8.0 and 8.9 on the Richter sca...
question.questiontext: Every year, an earthquake of magnitude between 8.0 and 8.9 on the Richter scale, will be experienced somewhere in the world [Haughton, 1989].
question.generalfeedback: Every year, an earthquake of magnitude between 8.0 and 8.9 on the Richter scale will be experienced somewhere in the world [Haughton, 1989].

question.name: As the flame front propagates hot combustion products expand, resulting in a ...
question.questiontext: As the flame front propagates hot combustion products expand, resulting in a rapid pressure increase.
question.generalfeedback: As the flame front propagates, hot combustion products expand, resulting in a rapid pressure increase.

question.name: The concentrations of these gases, which are called greenhouse gases control ...
question.questiontext: The concentrations of these gases, which are called greenhouse gases control how much infrared radiation escapes.
question.generalfeedback: The concentrations of these gases, which are called greenhouse gases, control how much infrared radiation escapes.

question.name: After 1987 parachuting accidents decreased significantly because instructors ...
question.questiontext: After 1987 parachuting accidents decreased significantly because instructors started teaching novices with tandem jumps rather than static lines.
question.generalfeedback: After 1987, parachuting accidents decreased significantly because instructors started teaching novices with tandem jumps rather than static lines.

question.name: On May 18, 1980, a cloud of hot rock and gas surged northward from Mount St. ...
question.questiontext: On May 18, 1980, a cloud of hot rock and gas surged northward from Mount St. Helens.

question.name: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the ...
question.questiontext: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone, see Appendix A.
question.generalfeedback: The synergistic reactor contains a chamber in which the exhaust from the burning coal mixes with limestone, as discussed in Appendix A.

question.name: The local economy should benefit from the operation. Local property taxes ...
question.questiontext: The local economy should benefit from the operation. Local property taxes would decrease for area residents and the Nicolet Minerals Company, formerly the Crandon Mining Company, is expected to spend more than $40 million on local goods and services.
question.generalfeedback: The local economy should benefit from the operation. Local property taxes would decrease for area residents, and the Nicolet Minerals Company, formerly the Crandon Mining Company, is expected to spend more than $40 million on local goods and services.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 8 – Verb Agreement and Tense
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 8 – Verb Agreement and Tense'.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext:
Choose the correct verb in the sentences below.

  1. In the past three months, a new series of low-priced computers {#1}.

  2. The insurance company hopes that neither the architect nor the construction firm {#2} liable.

  3. In the next section, the criteria for assessing each system {#3}.

  4. To connect a temperature measurement circuit to the HC11 microcontroller, we added new hardware and developed new software. The added hardware controlled both the measurement and the display of the temperature. This hardware {#4} light emitting diodes that {#5} to Port B. Figure 1 {#6} a schematic of this hardware.

  5. Conclusion. This report {#7} a design of a temperature measurement circuit for the HC11 microcontroller.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=has been released#Because the subject "series" is singular in this sentence, the correct verb is "has."~have been released}

answer.feedback: Because the subject "series" is singular in this sentence, the correct verb is "has."

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:are held~=is held#With a "neither/nor" construction of the subject, the number of the noun closest to the verb determines the number of the verb. In this case, because the noun "firm" is singular, the verb is singular.}

answer.feedback: With a "neither/nor" construction of the subject, the number of the noun closest to the verb determines the number of the verb. In this case, because the noun "firm" is singular, the verb is singular.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=are given#The noun "criteria" is plural.~is given}

answer.feedback: The noun "criteria" is plural.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=included#In the first two sentences, the author has adopted a reference frame in which the circuit existed in the past. Therefore, for the rest of the document, that reference frame must be maintained. In reports that document the completion of a project, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame that exists after the experiment or design has been disassembled. In progress reports, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame in which the experiment or design still exists.~includes}

answer.feedback: In the first two sentences, the author has adopted a reference frame in which the circuit existed in the past. Therefore, for the rest of the document, that reference frame must be maintained. In reports that document the completion of a project, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame that exists after the experiment or design has been disassembled. In progress reports, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame in which the experiment or design still exists.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:attach~=attached#In the first two sentences, the author has adopted a reference frame in which the circuit existed in the past. Therefore, for the rest of the document, that reference frame must be maintained. In reports that document the completion of a project, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame that exists after the experiment or design has been disassembled. In progress reports, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame in which the experiment or design still exists.}

answer.feedback: In the first two sentences, the author has adopted a reference frame in which the circuit existed in the past. Therefore, for the rest of the document, that reference frame must be maintained. In reports that document the completion of a project, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame that exists after the experiment or design has been disassembled. In progress reports, engineers and scientists usually adopt a reference frame in which the experiment or design still exists.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:showed~=shows#Present tense is used here because the figure continues to show the readers a schematic of the hardware, even though the actual hardware has been disassembled. Such a use of present tense in the same paragraph that contains verbs in the past tense is not a tense error because the reference frame for the document remains constant.}

answer.feedback: Present tense is used here because the figure continues to show the readers a schematic of the hardware, even though the actual hardware has been disassembled. Such a use of present tense in the same paragraph that contains verbs in the past tense is not a tense error because the reference frame for the document remains constant.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=has presented#The present perfect tense is used here because most of the "presenting" has occurred in the past, but some "presenting" still remains. Note that in the "Introduction" of this report the tense choice for this sentence would be the present tense.~presented~presents}

answer.feedback: The present perfect tense is used here because most of the "presenting" has occurred in the past, but some "presenting" still remains. Note that in the "Introduction" of this report the tense choice for this sentence would be the present tense.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 9 – Possessives
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 9 – Possessives'.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext:
Choose the correct possessive form in the sentences below.

  • According the Department of Energy, if we were to set up an area of solar cells equal to 0.25 the area currently covered by our roads, these cells could supply our entire {#1} electrical needs.

  • With a rear-facing child seat, the top of the seat and the {#2} head will be in the deployment zone of the air bag.

  • When you receive my {#3} memo requesting your participation, please respond to her that your job description, as written, will not allow you to perform that type of work.

  • This section explains the function of each technique and describes {#4} advantages and disadvantages.

  • Since 1981, when the air traffic {#5} strike occurred, the number of controllers decreased from 16,200 to 14,300 [Krasner, 1997].

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:nations ~=nation's#In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's.~nations'}

answer.feedback: In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:infants~=infant's#In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's.~infants'}

answer.feedback: In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:boss~bosses~=boss's#In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's. Occasionally, you will have a noun, such as "Moses" or "Mount St. Helens" with an s-sound ending such that addition of the possessive does not cause an extra s syllable in the pronunciation. In such unusual cases, the singular possessive is formed by the addition of an apostrophe. Note that "boss" is not one of these cases. The possessive form adds an extra syllable and therefore 's.~boss'~bosses'}

answer.feedback: In general, to form the singular possessive of a noun, add 's. Occasionally, you will have a noun, such as "Moses" or "Mount St. Helens" with an s-sound ending such that addition of the possessive does not cause an extra s syllable in the pronunciation. In such unusual cases, the singular possessive is formed by the addition of an apostrophe. Note that "boss" is not one of these cases. The possessive form adds an extra syllable and therefore 's.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=its~it's~its'}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:controller's~=controllers'#In general, to form the possessive of a plural noun, simply add an apostrophe to the plural form.}

answer.feedback: In general, to form the possessive of a plural noun, simply add an apostrophe to the plural form.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 10 – Word Choice (Advanced)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 10 – Word Choice (Advanced)'.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext:
Choose the correct usage in the sentences below.

  1. During the past decade, our division has made {#1} improvements to the automobile's exhaust system.

  2. Using geothermal energy does not pollute the environment {#2} the burning of fossil fuels does.

  3. The new material is {#3} of plastic and iodine.

  4. From the den, the male wolf ventured much {#4} than the female.

  5. John is {#5} to that type of solution.

  6. The truss had spans of 210 feet and was {#6} 20 feet deep.

  7. The values of the transfer coefficients were lowered {#7} outgassing.

  8. The {#8} of the solar receiver's tower surprised the visiting officials.

  9. Compared {#9} molten salt, liquid sodium is a much more dangerous heat transfer fluid.

  10. The turbulence values of that report were different {#10} the results of ours.

  11. The new antidote made the patients feel {#11}.

  12. Thank you for the job offer. I am {#12} to begin work next month.

  13. The fourth design option was {#13}.

  14. Chicken is {#14} to eat.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:continuous~=continual#If the team were to make "continuous" improvements on the exhaust system over the past decade, then they would be making those improvements day and night without interruption for sleep or food. Such a scenario is highly unlikely.}

answer.feedback: If the team were to make "continuous" improvements on the exhaust system over the past decade, then they would be making those improvements day and night without interruption for sleep or food. Such a scenario is highly unlikely.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=as#The word "as" is appropriate because a clause, rather than a phrase, follows.~like}

answer.feedback: The word "as" is appropriate because a clause, rather than a phrase, follows.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=composed#made~consisted}

answer.feedback: made

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=farther~further}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:adverse~=averse#The word "averse" means "unwilling"; "adverse" means "unfavourable."}

answer.feedback: The word "averse" means "unwilling"; "adverse" means "unfavourable."

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=more than#Use "greater than" or "more than" when referring to quantity. Otherwise, confusion could result because "over" is often used to indicate position.~over}

answer.feedback: Use "greater than" or "more than" when referring to quantity. Otherwise, confusion could result because "over" is often used to indicate position.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=because of~as of}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:enormity~=enormousness#The word "enormousness" refers to a great size; the word "enormity" means "horror."}

answer.feedback: The word "enormousness" refers to a great size; the word "enormity" means "horror."

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:to~=with#You compare things of the same class "with" each other and things of different classes "to" each other. For instance, you compare three automobiles with each on the criteria of performance, cost, and safety, but Freud compared the ego and the id to a horse and his rider.}

answer.feedback: You compare things of the same class "with" each other and things of different classes "to" each other. For instance, you compare three automobiles with each on the criteria of performance, cost, and safety, but Freud compared the ego and the id to a horse and his rider.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=from~than}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=nauseated#The word "nauseated" means feeling sick to one's stomach, while the word "nauseous" means causing one to feel sick to one's stomach. For that reason, you would write that "the patients were nauseated," and that "the acrid odours were nauseous."~nauseous}

answer.feedback: The word "nauseated" means feeling sick to one's stomach, while the word "nauseous" means causing one to feel sick to one's stomach. For that reason, you would write that "the patients were nauseated," and that "the acrid odours were nauseous."

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:anxious~=eager#The word "anxious" means to expect with anxiety, while the word "eager" means to expect with enthusiasm. While the new hire in the example might feel anxiety about the new job, he or she most likely intends to convey the feeling of enthusiasm to the employer.}

answer.feedback: The word "anxious" means to expect with anxiety, while the word "eager" means to expect with enthusiasm. While the new hire in the example might feel anxiety about the new job, he or she most likely intends to convey the feeling of enthusiasm to the employer.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:rather unique~=unique~very unique}

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=healthful#The word "healthy" means in a state of good health. This meaning does not apply here--chances are that the chicken is dead. "Healthful" means promoting good health.~healthy}

answer.feedback: The word "healthy" means in a state of good health. This meaning does not apply here--chances are that the chicken is dead. "Healthful" means promoting good health.

question_category.name: Default for Exercise 11 – Expressing Numbers
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Exercise 11 – Expressing Numbers'.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext:
In the exercise below, decide the appropriate way to express the number.

  1. The Titanic was nearly 900 feet long, stood {#1} stories high, and weighed an incredible 46 thousand tons.

  2. The Charpy test is run by holding the coupon against a steel backing and striking the coupon with a 67-pound pendulum on a {#2}.

  3. {#3}

  4. The maximum amperage for each of the two devices is {#4}.

  5. In its day, the Titanic cost more than {#5} to construct.

  6. During that time the water temperature dropped {#6}.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=25#Because the sentence contains two other numerals that present parallel information, the number "twenty-five" should also be expressed as a numeral, "25." Note that if the other two numerals were not presenting parallel information in the same paragraph, then the format's convention would dictate whether "twenty-five" should be written out or expressed as a numeral.~twenty-five}

answer.feedback: Because the sentence contains two other numerals that present parallel information, the number "twenty-five" should also be expressed as a numeral, "25." Note that if the other two numerals were not presenting parallel information in the same paragraph, then the format's convention would dictate whether "twenty-five" should be written out or expressed as a numeral.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=2-foot arm#Measurements are expressed as numerals.~two-foot arm}

answer.feedback: Measurements are expressed as numerals.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:1522 people perished when the Titanic sank.~=When the Titanic sank, 1522 people perished. #In English, it is improper to begin a sentence with a numeral. Note that writing the number out here would have been technically correct, but difficult for the audience to read. For that reason, it is better to rearrange the sentence. Also note that having a comma after the first digit (1,522) depends on your format's convention.}

answer.answertext: 1522 people perished when the Titanic sank.
When the Titanic sank, 1522 people perished.
answer.feedback: In English, it is improper to begin a sentence with a numeral. Note that writing the number out here would have been technically correct, but difficult for the audience to read. For that reason, it is better to rearrange the sentence. Also note that having a comma after the first digit (1,522) depends on your format's convention.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=3 A#Writing out the number "two" here is appropriate in most conventions because the number is simply arrived at by counting, and in most conventions, counted numbers can be written out if they can be expressed in a single word. On the other hand, the numeral "3" is appropriate because it was arrived at by measuring, and measurements are always expressed as numerals when the units are abbreviated.~three A}

answer.feedback: Writing out the number "two" here is appropriate in most conventions because the number is simply arrived at by counting, and in most conventions, counted numbers can be written out if they can be expressed in a single word. On the other hand, the numeral "3" is appropriate because it was arrived at by measuring, and measurements are always expressed as numerals when the units are abbreviated.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:=$7.5 million#With large numbers, it is acceptable to write out part of the number to avoid a string of zeroes. Note that "7.5" has to be a numeral on two counts: it contains a decimal, and it represents a monetary figure. ~$7,500,000~seven and one-half million dollars}

answer.feedback: With large numbers, it is acceptable to write out part of the number to avoid a string of zeroes. Note that "7.5" has to be a numeral on two counts: it contains a decimal, and it represents a monetary figure.

question.name: Questions
question.questiontext: {1:MC:.6 K~=0.6 K#A digit has to appear before the decimal.~zero point six degrees Kelvin}

answer.feedback: A digit has to appear before the decimal.

question_category.name: Default for Logical Fallacies - Exercise
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Logical Fallacies - Exercise'.

question.name: The missile theory has expert witnesses. For example, just before Flight 800 ...
question.questiontext: The missile theory has expert witnesses. For example, just before Flight 800 broke into flames, private pilot Sven Faret reported that he saw "a little pin flash on the ground." In his view, that flash "looked like a rocket launch."

question.name: If we begin considering theories other than the one the NTSB is pursuing, the...
question.questiontext: If we begin considering theories other than the one the NTSB is pursuing, the investigation will run in so many directions that we'll never solve anything.

question.name: Mr. Kadlec believes that this downing won't be solved. "Amelia Earhart ...
question.questiontext: Mr. Kadlec believes that this downing won't be solved. "Amelia Earhart crashed," he said. "No one knows why she crashed."

question.name: The FBI is still convinced that it was a bomb that brought down the aircraft....
question.questiontext: The FBI is still convinced that it was a bomb that brought down the aircraft. "The public believes it was a bomb," said Agent John Hunt. "Polls taken the day after the crash indicate that more than 75% of Americans believe it was terrorist's bomb."

question.name: Now that we know explosives had been placed aboard the plane for dog-sniffing...
question.questiontext: Now that we know explosives had been placed aboard the plane for dog-sniffing tests five weeks before the crash, the FBI's discovery of bomb traces in the cabin is a "dud."

question.name: If it wasn't a missile, a bomb, or mechanical failure, then all that's left ...
question.questiontext: If it wasn't a missile, a bomb, or mechanical failure, then all that's left is a meteorite.

question.name: The missile theory has no merit. It arose from Pierre Salinger, and he's a ...
question.questiontext: The missile theory has no merit. It arose from Pierre Salinger, and he's a kook. Not only is he a reporter, but he's French.

question.name: One thing that people aren't considering enough is that the plane went down ...
question.questiontext: One thing that people aren't considering enough is that the plane went down during an election year. Elections bring out the worst in people, a clear example being the Teapot Dome Scandal of 1920.

question_category.name: Default for Send a reply
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Send a reply'.

question.name: Letter Writing
question.questiontext: Use the online editor to write the letter. When the time is over, your response will be automatically saved.

question_category.name: Default for Invitation to product presentation
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Invitation to product presentation'.

question.name: Email
question.questiontext:
The toy which you designed and which you have been working on is almost complete. Soon, it will be sent to the production line for serial production. However, before that, you need to provide the Marketing Department of the company  with very detailed information so that they can design a marketing strategy - together with advertising options, price ranges for different periods of the year, etc.

You were introduced to the director of the Marketing Department, Mary O'Connell, in a company meeting several weeks ago but she might not remember your name or your position in the company because there were many new employees present at the meeting. Write her an email and invite her to the product presentation briefing to be held in the company premises.

question_category.name: Default for Invitation to product presentation
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Invitation to product presentation'.

question.name: Email
question.questiontext: You are Mary O'Connell, Director of the Marketing Department of ToiToi Company. You have only just received an email about an invitation to a briefing about a new product. Write and send your reply.
